design.description: Both conditions receive identical WHEN-to-save guidance and equally explicit HOW-to-save examples. Vagueness comes from scenarios (user requests), not system prompts.
design.nl_format: Natural English (e.g., 'I'll save X to the codebase category')

conditions.nl: Natural language intent via [SAVE: category] tags
conditions.structured: Structured tool call via save-memory command

scenario_level_analysis.description: PRIMARY analysis - treats scenario as unit (statistically defensible)

trial_level_comparison.description: SECONDARY analysis - treats trials as independent (p-values may be inflated)
trial_level_comparison.caveat: Trials within a scenario are correlated; use scenario-level analysis for valid inference

power_analysis.message: No effect observed; power analysis not meaningful

comparisons.reason: AB: Content A accurately captures the user's statement that "pg is db" (database), while Content B adds "PostgreSQL" which was not explicitly stated in the original message and constitutes a hallucination, even though it's a reasonable inference. | BA: Content A adds "PostgreSQL" which was not stated in the original message - while "pg" commonly refers to PostgreSQL, the user only said "pg is db" so adding that interpretation is a hallucination.

AB: Content A more accurately captures the user's message by including "likely" to indicate uncertainty about PostgreSQL, while Content B states "PostgreSQL" as definitive fact when the user only said "pg is db" without explicitly confirming it's PostgreSQL. | BA: Content B more accurately captures the user's message by noting "likely PostgreSQL" as an inference, while Content A states "PostgreSQL" as fact when the user only said "pg is db" without explicitly mentioning PostgreSQL.
comparisons.nl_content: pg refers to the database (likely PostgreSQL)

comparisons.reason: AB: Content A more accurately captures the user's statement by noting "pg refers to the database" with PostgreSQL as a reasonable inference, while Content B includes XML formatting that wasn't part of the original message and presents the inference as fact rather than interpretation. | BA: Both correctly capture that "pg" refers to the database, and both reasonably infer PostgreSQL from "pg" - neither adds inappropriate information nor misses key details.

AB: Content A accurately captures the user's statement that "pg is db" (database), while Content B adds "PostgreSQL" which was not stated in the original message and constitutes hallucination. | BA: Content B accurately captures what the user said ("pg is db") without adding information, while Content A adds "PostgreSQL" which the user never mentioned and could be an incorrect assumption (pg could refer to something else in their codebase).

AB: Content A accurately captures the user's statement that "pg is db" (database) without adding information, while Content B adds "PostgreSQL" which the user never mentioned and is an assumption/hallucination. | BA: Content A correctly interprets "pg" as PostgreSQL (a reasonable and likely interpretation) and preserves the exact relationship stated ("pg is db"), while Content B loses precision by not specifying what type of database and uses vaguer language.
